text: BOTTLE 37 CL from Koelschtrinker. Danke! Pitch black, dark espresso head. Huge, luscious chocolate glazed smoky dark fruit infused with Bourbon. The taste is incredibly intense for a beer of its strength, black chocolate and dark treacle with a strong acrid coffee note, followed by a lot of barrel goodness - whisky spice and heat, as well as it caramel and vanilla side. Thick full smooth body. Slightly ashy finish with moderate chili heat. Excellent.
caramel, hay, coffee, roasty, chocolate, alcohol, woody, smoke, black, hazy, brown foam, heavy cloying sweetness, medium bitterness, full body, oily feel, soft carbonation, bitter, long finish,

375ml bottle. Fast schwarze Farbe, mittelgroße stabile bräunliche schaumkrone. Geruch süß schokoladig, röstmalzig, leicht oxidiert. Geschmack süß schokoladig malzig, leicht oxidiert, zum Ende etwas schärfer, dezente Chilinoten.
Vollmundig malziger Antrunk. Weich, das Chili ist eher riechbar als geschmacklich erkennbar. Noten von Schokolade, süffig, zum Ende würziger. 10/12/12/11/12/11

Sampled from 0.375 l bottle. Pitch black with a brown head. Sweetish-malty, moderately roasty aroma of dark chocolate, coffee, vanilla, bourbon and some licorice. Sweetish-malty, moderately roasty taste of dark chocolate, coffee, licorice, some tar, ash, vanilla and bourbon, followed by a medium long, moderately roasty-bitter, slightly warming-alcoholic and moderately peppery-spicy finish. Medium body, smooth and slightly effervescent mouthfeel, soft carbonation. Very nice!

375 ml bottle. Pours black with moderate tan head. Aromas of black syrupy chocolate, kahlua, spicy oak, oily roasted malts and a bit of coconut. Flavors of dry dark chocolate, roasted malts, burnt peppers, soy sauce, and a hit of vanilla and licorice. Wonderful.

Memory banks rate, drank a lot of this when I was getting in to beer, still think its a great drink, never mind beer. So much going on. Red wine barrels, as I recall. Dark brown, thin but persistent tan head. Aromas of chocolate, faint chilli, red wine, oak, vanilla. Taste is more of the same.

375 ml bottle picked up locally at home. Pours dark brown to black in color with a small beige head. The aroma and flavor have roasted malt, peppery spice, wood, mild barrel notes, a mild smoked character, the heat enhances rather than dominates the beer, drinkable, pretty solid.
On tap at Wapigs, Copenhagen. Pours black with brown head. Roasted malts, chocolate, licorice, wood. Hint of chilli.

375ml bottle. Black color with beige brown head. Aroma is malty, roasted, chocolate, vanilla, wood, alcohol, light dark fruits. Sweet and bitter taste like aroma with some spicy notes. Medium to full oily silky body.

Draft at Mikkeller Bar in Seoul. Deep red, dark colour and sticky thin head. Aroma of spice and the bourbon. Tender palate starts, spicy dark malts taste like coffee and another one of yeasts. And finishes with following flavour of yeasts and the bourbon, not strong. Pretty good.

Bottle (375 ml). Split 3-ways.

Appearance: Dark brown with a medium brown head and little lacing. 

Aroma: Cocoa, bourbon, spicy/chili notes, light vegetal presence and roasted malts.

Taste: Light to moderate acidic presence. Cocoa, anise, bourbon, chili and cinnamon. 

Palate: Medium body. Medium carbonation. Warming finish from the chipotle chilis that gives the impression that the beer has a much higher abv. 

Overall: Good spicy porter that is drinking like an Imperial Porter. Tasty. Decent balance considering the adjuncts. I liked it.

Bottle 375ml.
Pours black with medium beige head. Good lacing. Aroma is of coffee, roasted malt, chocolate. Taste is of acidity, roasted malt, spices, alcohol, warming chipotle. Palate: Full bodied. Soft carbonation. Slightly burning. Overall: OK. Quite spicy/hot.
Bottle. Black pour with creamy brown gold foam. Aroma is roasty, molasses, anise, spicy. Taste is rich, cocoa, spicy, cinnamon. Palate is med-full bodied, light-med carbonation. Nice stuff.

375 ml bottle. Pours an opaque, dark brown with a huge, frothy, brown head that laces. Rich chocolate aroma with roasted malt, oak and a hint of chili. Sweet flavour of chocolate, roasted malt, bourbon, oak, lighter notes of chili, vanilla and smoke with a subtle warming alcohol finish. Full body with a creamy, oily texture and soft carbonation. A well balanced, excellent brew.
Bottle split 3 ways. Pitch black pour with a a small tan head. Lots and lots of dark chocolate, some vanilla, light soy sauce, cocoa powder and some light licorice. Didnt get any chili hat though.

shared bottle. poured a dark murky brown colour with a tanned head. roasted malts, chocolate, chili pepper, peppers, caramel, some vanilla and oak hints, even a bit more heat as it warms up. pretty full bodied beer for the 6.6% abv

Black in colour, very thin tan head, light lacing.
Aroma of chocolate, liquorice, light peppery spice.
Flavour is of light pepper, some dark chocolate, some smoke.
Thin mouthfeel, some spice, light body, mild carbonation.
Finishes with some peppery spice, long.
Weaker body then expected after the fantastic aroma, still quite good though.

Bottle. Black in color with a tan head, looks nice alright. Upfront you get some wooden oak, bit of vanilla, campfire, roasted malty chococolate and spicy pepppers in aroma. Dark chocolate, bit of green vegetable notes, some hints of bourbon and little bit of burning pepper in taste. Feels a lot heavier than one could imagine from the abv. Bit of earthyness and more of smokey chili burning notes in the end. One of the porters Ive had in a while for sure.

Botella de 37.5 cl de 2d2dspuma, en el momento, tomada el 18-10-2014. Lote y fcpref ilegible. Color negro intenso con bastante espuma oscura. Aromas herbáceos y de maltas tostadas y quemadas con especias y toque de chile. Cuerpo medio con 6.6 vol y un increíble sabor. Sabores intensos de maltas tostadas y quemadas, algo ahumadas con herbáceos verdes y especias mas algo de cacao y con un agradable toque de maderas ligeramente dulces y quemadas con regusto de bourbon. Sensación de picante perfectamente combinada con todo lo anterior y que junto con ello perdura en boca por un buen rato. Un nuevo y gran aporte de sabor para una cerveza de por si ya maravillosa. Increíble.
Aroma is completely Mexican food or a marinade for a steak! Taste is roasted malts, coffee, chocolate and a nice smoked chilli sting to finish it off!

Noire. Beau collet brun moka. 

Nez: chocolat. Malté. Torréfié. Boisé. Whisky/bois. Caramel salé. 

Bouche: sucré. Boisé. Piquante (chipotle). Vanillé. Crémeuse. Chocolat au piment. Whisky subtile. Finale boisé et épicé/piquante. 

Original. J'aime beaucoup.

"Labeled as bourbon barreled chipotle porter. Another fantastic brew that stands up to the barreling and has great body with a low abv of 6.6. Better than the speyside as it is near perfect balance between toasted coffee and chocolate malt, peppers, and Bourbon. Great brew."
Bottle at home. Pours black, nose is chocolate, vanilla, toffee, taste is more of the same, light chilli burn.

Looks.. Deepest darkest brown, dark med head.
Smells.. Coffee, choc, oak, herbs, some bourbon.
Tastes..coffee and dark milk choc, herbs, bourbon, vanilla and a slow burn chipotle that warms in your chest. Mikkeller good.

Bottle. Pours a deep black with a thin mocca head. Aromas of sweet chili, slight bourbon, vanilla, pepper. Taste is pepper, chili, still slight bourbon (wouldve liked more), jalapenos, slight roasted malt. Aftertaste is roasty and dry. Chili comes through with the heat. Medium mouthfeel. Couldve been thicker.

Bottle. Pours pitch black with a dense brown head. Aroma has roast, jalapeño, bourbon, hint of smoke and some chocolate. Slightly watery. Taste has a bitter roast, coffee, dark bitter chocolate, some sweetness and some bourbon. The body is a little watery, but the beer has a lot of heat in the end from the chili. Medium carb.

Bottle from a trade with Slovaksniper, thanks Pat. Pours true black and fluffy light brown head, lots of spotty lace. Nose is not very pleasing, pepper-like, light malt. Tastes much better than it smells. Roasted and sweet malt, there is a bit of spicy heat, but very slight. There is a little of that vanilla barrel character. Surprisingly good.
Sampled at esbls. Very dark and a little angry looking. Big barrel notes with roast and malts. Soy. Big flavor is almost as angry as angry as the aroma. Good.

Bottle 
Pours very dark brown , with a mocha head . 
Smell is sweet , dark, heavy , bit spices, very full and thick . Reminds me of when I had my first few mikkeller Imperial stouts , even ! And tháts a compliment !
Touch to much carbo , but still doable . 
INTENSE chocolate taste ( I LOVE that ! ) and bitterness that naturally joins that . Not too much of the peppers , just hints, that blend in perfectly .
Mouthfeel is very good , full , but I midd thickness . In a way, the body is perfect for this ABV , but I rate blindly and simply prefer thicker beer . AKA no perfection here ( not possible neither I guess ) So I cannot give that part 5/5 . 
I expected this one to be mediocer to me at best. I am surprised to discover it is actually one of the best mikkellers yet , on about 110 I drank of them . At this ABV , at this price ? Hell yes, tháts how its done !

Pours black with a medium creamy tan head. Aroma is coffee, dark chocolate, muscovado sugar, slight liqourice and bourbon. Taste is coffee, dark chocolate, nuscovado sugar, dark red berries, bourbon. Mouthfeel is quite dry and astringent with low carbonation. Aftertaste is coffee, dark chocolate and a slight chili hint though nowhere near as dominating as the non-barrel version. Very good though!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Tap @ Mikkeller & Friends 8/2-2014. Trä, vanilj, chili, rostad malt, fyllig, oljig koncistens.

375 ml bottle poured a clear dark reddish brown with a small lasting creamy brown head. Aromas of dark chocolate, roasted malt, chipotles, oak and light bourbon. Palate was medium to full bodied and smooth. Flavors of dark chocolate, roasted malt, chipotles, oak and light bourbon with a smooth lingering chocolate finish.

[Bottle (375ml) c/o Glouglouburp] Pours a very dark amber-brown, almost black, with an average size long-lasting frothy light-brown head. Minimal lacing. Aroma is fruity first followed by roasted malt, chocolate, wood, light smoke, light coffee, vanilla and more -- quite nice. Nice flavour, smoky and fruity, along with roasted malt, chocolate, a bit of alcohol, wood, some leafy hops and a long, semi-big roasty/bitter finish. Medium bodied. An enjoyable beer, and nice to have a barrel-aged beer with this low an abv.
Bottle @ Søren formand. Pitch black, big tan head that settles nicely, great lacing. Aroma, roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, spicy. Taste, roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, chillies, bourbon notes.

From notes, courtesy or Armando629, hálás köszönet! Poured black, with a decent brwon head. Aroma of dark chocolate, oak, bourbon, red grapes, earth, ash, paprika. Dense body with lively carbonation. Dark fruity somewhat bitter aftertaste that lasts. Good one.

Bottle split at JFs, from BD Online, 26/12/13.
Pitch black with a good sized dirty tan head that thins a little then retains.
Nose is roast malt, light smoke, sugars, earthy cocoa, spice, light booze. light vinegar, dark fruits.
Taste comprises cocoa, chipotle, dark toffee, green pepper, spice, molasses, chocolate notes.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, dry spiced closure with light chilli heat.
Pretty good stuff for the style, decent all round balance and the chilli heat is well pitched.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text:
375ml bottle from Bierkompass

Pours pitch black with a smooth light brown head. Aroma of roasted malts, wood, oak, vanilla, spices, warming peppery notes and dark chocolate. Taste is smooth, roasty, spicy and woody with notes of vanilla, oak, pepper, hints of warming chili and dark chocolate. Finish is roasty, smooth and tingling with hints of woody oaky notes, warming chili and dark chocolate. Nice, quite balanced and complex porter with a nice touch of warming chili and bourbony notes.

Chocolate, coffee and smoky chipotle immediate off the nose and palate. Surprisingly drinkable despite it's intense taste. Really enjoyed

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

How: Bottle.
Where: Drankencentrale de Hopduvel, Gent.
Appearance: Black colour with a brown head.
Aroma: Chocolate, caramel, roasted malt, spices, some vanilla.
Body: Full body with a low carbonation.
Flavour: Chocolate, a little vanilla, spices, roasted malt, a bit of chili, alcohol.

375 ml bottle (taken from notes - 18/02/2011). Pours light black with a fine marroonish head with grey hue. Aroma: roasted coffee, subtle vanilla and bourbon. Taste is quite balanced to be a Mikkeller porter and the mouthfeel is quite subtle and not too watery. Nice.
Pitch black pour, mocca head with superb lacing. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, licorice, bourbon, and some chilipunches towards the finish. Taste is medium sweet medium bitter, long finish.

Det här var en överrasking, efter att ha druckit den vanliga texas ranger så hade jag inga höga förhoppningar på den här. Men dra på trissor, ölen var otroligt god och välbalanserad med fina toner av kaffe och chili. Om man ska dricka någon av texas ranger ölen så är det den här jag rekommenderar
Kolsvart men brunt skum. Mycket kaffe. Väldigt väldigt balanserad i smak och kropp.
Spicy, but just about the perfect amount. The bourbon isbarely there but i think it adds nicely. Only complaint is it is very thin.

Dark black in color with mahogany head... Smoke, oak, bourbon notes on the nose... Flavor is roasted malts, coffee, oak, smoke... Bourbon not super prevalent... Smoke on the palate... Solid 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours medium black with tan head. Nose is of peppers, molassis, raisins and roast malt. Taste is similar but with a tobasco acidic feel. Body is medium. Not much from the barrel.This was an older bottle, I will re-rate if anything different from the current version I just picked up. I cant imagine with the lower abv this is meant to be aged for long.

Tap at mikkeller bar, copenhagen. Black color, brown head, perfect. Aroma is roasted malts, spices, chilis, coffee. Taste has been balanced during aging (drank normal ranger few day ago), hint of chilis, barrels, licorice, coffee.

Bottle - The sweet bourbon notes mingle with chocolate and vanilla to give a beautiful if not dessert like nose. Jet brown with a reddish dark brown head. Bourbon starts and milk chocolate finishes. The heat in the regular version is almost non existent but does peak through in the finish. I think this is better than the original although the chipotle is even further in this version.
Kolsvart med ganska stort mörkbrunt skum! Kaffe och chili i doften och smaken även lite bränt! Chilin bränner lite skönt på tungan! Köp!

Pours black into a tulip. Mocha head with medium retention recedes to whisper surface. Chocolate and smoked chipotle aromas. Thin with sweet chocolate upfront turning to warming chipotle before the lasting slight oak espresso finish.

from Erzbierschof - black beer under a persistent dark beige foam; some sharpness comes first, woody tones appear in the background; hazelnut and molasses; a good malt backbone, earthy notes, pretty dry and sharp woody, roasted and nutty finish

Bottle shared @Dean Sticky Floor Tasting 2. Pours a pitch black beer with a creamy, beige head on top. Aroma is full of bourbon barrels, some pepper and chocolate with a nice oaky presence. Incredibly full flavoured beer for such a low abv beer. Sweet and chocolate, very slight pepper burn in the end. Malty and thick mouthfeel, great!

Bottle from DeMolenBeershop, 2010 vintage.
Pours dark brown with a big brown head.
Aroma is as the regular Texas Ranger but with a lot of sweet notes and some wood from the bourbon.
Taste is also pretty much like the regular version but with bourbon notes, wood and the chili heat and hop bitterness has faded away quite a bit. More mellow and smooth than the regular ranger but that is probably the barrel ageing+3 years of cellaring.
Bottle shared @ Deans Sticky Floor Tasting II. Aroma of dark chocolate, molasses, vanilla, with noticeable peppers. Taste is light chocolate, molasses, with the peppers building in the finish
Pours dark brown with a thick Brown head.  Nice aroma of wood and chocolate. Taste is spicy, molasses, earthy, coffee. Spicy finish.  Very good.

Bottle shared at Deans sticky floor tasting 2 thanks to Mrhangover.  Pours almost black with a small biege head.  Aroma of oak, roast, milk chocolate, toffee, fudge, light vanilla.  Flavour is moderate to heavy sweet and moderate bitter.  Thick chewy mouthfeel with a nice kick from the peppers in the finish and warming the more you drink.  Medium to full bodied with soft carbonation.

35cl bottle courtesy of MrHangover @DSFT2
Thin tan head.  Clear peaty black pour.  Subtle chilli and woody notes.  Nice blend.
375 ml bottle pours black with a tan head.  Aroma of malts, vanilla, chili and chocolate.  Taste is the chilis, malts and coffee.

bottle, texan version .. . pours a deep brown black .. . foam level is quite good .. . tar, sweet charcoal, and mild chipolte .. . heat level is minimal .. . a mild beer .. . . How is your appetite?   My appetite is too good. I just want to eat everything.

Pours black with a thin brown head; aroma of black chocolate, vanilla and whiskey - very nice; tastes initially of chocolate, then the chilli comes at you slowly at first, but youre well aware of it by the swallow; heat and spice lingers on the finish; its not overpowering but it just doesnt work for me; barrel aging is always a dangerous game and nothing Ive tasted suggests chilli in beer is a good thing; the bourbon/chilli combo here is messy and feels like weirdness for weirdness sake.

375ml bottle.  Pours a very dark brown, almost black, body with a nice tight bubbled frothy brown head that left some delicate lacing.  The nose isnt all that different than the regular version of this, still lots of chocolate malt and lesser roastiness, and the chipotle chili pepper that underlies it all.  Theres a little touch of smoke and barrel character to this, but its pretty minimal, just a slightly medicinal note.  The flavor (at least at this point, the bottle is several months old from the date of purchase), is dominated by the Porter notes of chocolate malt and light roast.  The chili pepper is still in here, but the level is pretty subtle with just a light spiciness on the late finish.  Minimal suggestions of the smoked malt.  Hard to really pick up much character from the barrel treatment.  Except for the light medicinal note on the finish, I dont really get any barrel character.  Medium to full bodied, very chewy and thick for this ABV, soft minimal carbonation level.  Pretty enjoyable Porter, but I think the pepper was a bit more aggressive when it first came out (Didnt rate it way back when).

375ml bottle. Pitch black colour with huge, creamy, fully lasting, superbly lacing, brown head. Complex dark malty aroma with notes of dark chocolate, treacle, roast, a touch of vanilla, some leather, cautious peppery hints of chili in the nose, hoppy overtones. Taste is initially dry, minimally soapy, later minimally sweet dark malty, hints of treacle and chocolate, a touch of vanilla, then again dry, roasty, minimally soapy, herbal hoppy overtones; lasting peppery finish. Compared to the regular version slightly disappointing in taste. As so often I cant see any improvement by barrel aging; but after all in this, contrary to many other cases, better than annihilating the genuine beer.

Poura black with low deep tan head. Aroma is coffee, chili, smoke. Taste is chipotle sweet with a distinct smoke bitterness. Body is light and unbalanced. Prefer the normal one.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draft. Black. Small brown head. Chocolate, spicy, roasty, subtle pepper, wood and bourbon. Nicely balanced and smooth. The heat flows perfectly. Lip tingling good.

Bottle:
Black...reverse-cascade pour, dark brown head.
Strong bourbon aroma, peppered meat.
Taste is vanilla, chocolate, chipotle, black pepper....
thick.....
Wonderful...nice sedate chile burn.

Bottle. 6.6%. Best before 15.06.13(?). Pours black with a khaki/brown head. Decent lacing. Aroma is somewhat roasted, with a tart fruity note mixed with a slight citrusy sourness. Not very porter-like, but rather nice. As it wams, dark fruit notes come out, as well as a hint of vanilla. Roasted flavour, a bit tart and wiht a light liquorice note. Dark fruit notes as it warms. Finish is dark fruits and coffee with a lingering bitter coffee note and a mild chili burn. Overall pretty good. 28.04.13.
A very good strong flavor of chokolate and coffee, with fruity notes like wine and a bit sourness. Dark brown in color with a white head.

In short: A surprisingly rich bourbonny small beer with mild hot spiciness.  Very good.
How: Bottle 375ml, consumed with some age on it but still 8 months before expiration date.
The look: Black body topped by a large brown head with good retention.
In long: Nose has only light notes of the hot spiciness of the base beer, 
Taste is loaded with creamy blackened malts, a lot of vanilla, rich caramel, woody bourbon, well integrated mild notes of hot spiciness helping to distract from the sweetness, some peat, soy sauce, notes of creamy chocolate fudge.  Very full body with a tickling carbonation.  There aintt many low abv Bourbon Barrel Aged beers out there, but this Texas Ranger Barrel Aged offers a corpulence and an intensity that can match that of most BBA beers twice its size.  Quite different from the base beer, less spicy and with a better integration of the spices, less chocolaty, richer body and of course more vanilla and bourbon.  I actually much preferred this barrel version over the base beer.  I love beer, apparently Im an obsessive beer drinker, but in reality when Im at home I often go 20 or 30 minutes without even thinking about opening a bottle of beer, sometimes even more (depending on how long it takes me to drink the last bottle I opened).

bottled. Very black with a thick brown head. Very comlex and deep aroma, some dark chocolate, cocoa, smoke, oak and maybe some soy.  Deep flavour profile, long bitter finish with huge amount of burn and smoke. Bourbon is not very obvious but comes very nice through in the finish. World class

From bottle. Black with a brown head. Aroma is hard roasted malt, dark chocolate, peated smoke, chili and vanilla. Flavor is quite sweet and rather bitter. Dry and bitter finish, with little in the way of chili burning, which means good for me. Very nice complex brew.

375 mL green bottle.  Nice looking beer - shows reddish where the light comes through.  Spice in the nose, although not necessarily heat or smoke.  In the flavour, the peppers really dont show up until the end.  Smoke shows up more as it warms.  Chipotle is subtle.  Good porter.

375 ml bottle @cimmeria, Oviedo. Liquor aromas. Pours very dark, nice cremay tan head. Full body, oily texture, soft carbonation. Taste is liquor, some spicy, roasty, hot after a while. Very well balanced, rounded. Enjoyable.

Tap @ Mikkeller Bar. Pours black with a tan head. Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, little vegatables, peppers, light bourbon, smoke. Flavor of malts, dark chocolate, smoke, vegatabes, green chillies, wood, bourbon. Medium body, soft carbonation, pleasant warming chilly heat in the finish. 070313

Tap. Pitch black with a small dark brown head. Aroma is dark chocolate, brown sugar, roasted malt, light toffee, oak, light ashy. Taste is medium sweet and bitter. Medium/full body, oily texture, soft+ carbonation. Big bodied for the abv. Medium sweet and light sticky finish with some bitterness and a light chili burn. The barrel aging mellows it out and adds to the flavour without dominating. Good.

Tap. Pours near black with a light lacing and lasting dark brown creamy head. Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, grass, herbs, medicine, ash,vanilla, wood and a hint of smoke and coconut. Taste is medium sweet, bitter and has a light chili burn. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is average. Finishes with some alcoholic bite, astringent and light chili burn. Not as flamboyant/"in your face" as the regular.

Really rich aroma, mainly of chocolate. Some raisin, sticky brown sugar and coffee. Not much trace of the barrel. Taste is slightly earthy, the chocolate element comes through, coffee note and then a long subtle chilli heat to finish. Best beer Ive had in a long time.

Kolsvart i färgen med cappuccinoskum. Doftar kaffe, chokladkaka, lätt grönsakston som dras åt chili, förväntar mig en kraftig smak. Smakar rostat och bränt, söt choklad bitter choklad, chokladkaka, kaffe, man får leta lite med vaniljen finns där. Chilin kommer smygande långt bak i munnen. Otroligt balanserad

37.5 cl bottle @ home. Pours black with a little sediment and a tan head that leaves some lacing. Aroma is roasted malt, dark chocolate, bourbon, vanilla, and a little subtle chilli. Flavour is roasted malt, dark chocolate, and some subtle chilli. Not much trace of the barrel, though.
Pours black with brown head. Earthy vegetable aroma somewhat like dried mushrooms. Roasted malts chocolate and treacle taste. Silky velvet mouthfeel but with a spicy finish. Very nice.

Black in color with a small khaki head. Lightly metallic on the front end, but otherwise lots of roasted malt, chocolate, and spice. A bit of toffee sweetness, some vanilla, bourbon, and molasses. Not too much spice from the peppers. Nice earthy spice note to the flavor. Sweet toffee and vanilla, some bourbon, and a ton of roasted malt, dark chocolate, and coffee. A bit of licorice and some molasses, too.

Thanks Armando és Balázs! Egészen sötét, kis híján fekete színe van, vékony, egészen sötétbarna habbal. Illata földes, alkoholos meggybefőttes, picit, füstös és fás. Íze száraz kakaóporos, csokis, fás, szivarfüstös, kissé fanyar és picit csípős, paprikás. Elég testes és alig van benne buborék. Utóíze kesernyés, kissé csípős és száraz. Nagyon jól eltalálták a csili mennyiségét, nem vágja agyon az ízlelőbimbóinkat a túl sok kapszaicin, inkább izgalmassá teszi ezt a sört.

Pitch black pour, thinner brown head.  Aroma of Bourbon, black coffee, pepper in the aroma.  Bourbon dominates here, but I am getting hints of the pepper, dark chocolate, slight woodiness.  A bit of heat from the pepper here.  thick body, but very little carbonation.  the pepper was nicely inegrated, but the barrel aging took something away from this one.  Still fairly interesting.

Bottled, thanks to Josh from the other side of the world!  Poured near black with a very dark brown head.  The aroma picked up more spicy bourbon than anything else, with roasty, blended chocolates, vanilla, and smoked chiles beneath.. peaty smoke accented.. very nice.  The flavor found a little less of the bourbon than the nose indicated, and more of the smoked chiles.. roasty, lightly smoked chocolates supported.. vanilla, sweet bourbon, and dry oak around.. finished with a hit of sweet bourbon with trailing smoked peppers.  Medium-bodied with low carbonation on the palate.. very good balance between the porter, the peppers, and the barrel.

Bottle, enjoyed october 20th 2012. Dark brown body, small creamy tanned head. Aroma of oak, roasted malt, smoke and chili. Taste is sweet malty with raisins, bourbon, chocolate and chili pepper. Chili is more hidden than in the regular edition. Thick body and a good carbonation level, roasty chili aftertaste. A very nice beer!

(From notes 10 Oct, 2012) Bottle. Pitch black beer with a thick, brown head. Aroma has vanilla and coffee in it, with hints of liquorice. Tastes like dark roasted, bitter coffee. Creamy mouthfeel. Aftertaste is bitter and slight sourness. A very, very good porter. Loved it.

Bottled at Big Beers. This was very well balanced. It was a great base porter that had notes from the barrel and the chilis, but was not overpowered by either. Just a hint of chili spice overall. well made.

A-- Poured a dark, near black color. Slightly oily looking. Slight touches of red when pouring. Settled black. Half finger of dark marshmallow brown head. Slowly turned to film. Good head retention to this and left very spotty lacing on the sides of the glass. 

S-- Smells like char, cigar, and earthy in a way. Burnt carmel, burnt and smoked malts, hot chocolate sort of smell along with touches of oak. In the back of the smell I get smoked chipolte. Very interesting. 

T-- Milk chocolate, Carmel, wood, and a slight bite from the Chipolte. 

M-- Slick, clean feel. Dairy milk chocolate and Carmel. Not a lot of coffee taste. In the back and finish get the spice from the chipolte. Does have some heat associated with it. Barrel is very well hidden in this. Slight bits of vanilla before the Chipolte takes over. Low carbonation and medium feel. 

O-- Not a very big beer at all but this is done well. Easy to drink even with the heat in the finish. Not something I would have all the time but a good beer for something very different.

Bottle, at home; from my Minneapolis Town Hall glass. Pours deep, opaque black, with a toffee-brown hue. 1-finger thick, persistent tan head, nice lacing. Nose is big fudgy chocolate, really pretty chipotle spice, vanilla, icing sugar, roast. Flavours of mocha, cream, spice, honey. Just a stunning brew. Like a baby Hunahpu!

A tall, rough light beige head thrones above the black liquid. Not particularly pleasant nose focusing on ashes-like roasted malts with unsubtle corny, cerealic, rough bourbon connotations and more timid smoke/damp earth, anise and cigar-like nuances. There is not much else really, not much fruitiness to speak of, little alcohol and the chilis are not too obvious except for the smokey tang. In mouth though, its a different story. As the sips follow one another, the chipotle pile up their firey spiciness and are actually interestingly smokey, but the ash-like nature is perhaps not the best fit, making for a rough combo. It feels stronger than it is too, both because of the heat and related flavor intensity and because of the impressive, coating palate. Intensely tasty, perhaps too much so to be considered anything close to drinkable. Frankly, I found it unpolished and heading in every directions in mouth. One second, it seems that bourbon dominate, the other, chipotle, then ashes take over and there is not the appropriate bridges between those flavours for it to be called complex rather than rough and confused.

Det er efterhånden lidt tid siden jeg drak denne øl, og selvom mine noter består i bedste velgående er smagsindtrykkene efterhånden lidt slørede.
Jeg har skrevet at dette er et knaldsort bryg med flot, let luftigt, brunt skum og givet det et 4-tal. Dertil kommer så en krydret og humlet aroma med masser af chokolade og lakrids. Smagen afslører en ret sød udgave af en porter med masser af chokolade. Dertil kommer en undertone af sæbe, en let chilibrænden, noter af let træ og whiskey, men umiddelbart virker denne porter ikke så udpræget barrel aged som andre af Mikkellers øl. Dette skyldes måske at det er lykkedes at skjule alkoholen bedre, og alt i alt synes jeg da også at denne mængde af træ og whiskey er mere passende for ikke at overrumple resten af smagsindtrykkene i  Mikkellers altid gode øl. Humlebitterheden er hverken for kraftig eller glemt i baggrunden til fordel for lakrids og chokolade - nej, tværtimod velplaceret og velbalanceret. Derudover en yderst blød øl i munden, og virker overraskende let trods sine tunge smagsnuancer. Dette bidrager til endnu mere balance mellem det voldsomme og det smukke i dette forrygende bryg.

My Bottom Line :  
Fruity vanilla, roasted malts and molasses dwell in a sticky body lightened by fierce effervescence, while toasted, wooden notes take control of the finish. 

Further Personal Perceptions :  
-A rich head of foam slowly depletes into the darkness. 
-Vanilla-like bourbon is present from nose to aftertaste.
-Soy paste allusions are found.
-The mouthfeel is very heavy; there is no alcohol presence, but otherwise you might think this is close to the 10% range. 
-Smoke and chipotle are subdued at this point, overwhelmed by the hefty residual sugars. The regular Texas Ranger is friendlier AND more complex.
-For lovers of big beers, this one offers the potency of a 10% Imperial Porter without the alcohol heat and its effects.

Bottle.

holy dark pour! even meaner looking than the un-barreled version.

Bottle at local tasting. Pours almost black with no head at all. Aroma is smoked, peaty, bourbon and coffee. Taste is moderate chili, smooth and full bodied, lingering malty aftertaste.

Mikkeller barrel-aged Texas ranger. 375ml bottle purchased and drank  
and olbutikken. actually i believe this was compliments of the house or Toke!.. Pours a coffee like pour with lesser intense edges  
and topped with a light beige head... Aroma of bourbon and light wood

1/2 Bottle @ BrewDog Edinburgh. Black, with dark tan head. Unusual aroma of roasted malt, wine grapes, green peppers, smoky, oak. I would like to try this again, even if its very pricey.

14 June 2011, bottle. black, thin, slight brown lacing. gorgeous! vanilla soda w/ hersheys chocolate! lots of chocolate syrup. med/thin body and slightly fizzy. really interesting. oak comes out a lot in the taste. very dry oakiness. after a few drinks the chilli comes out a lot! very spicy. but spiciness doesnt linger. lovely.

33cl. Pours dark and opaque with a small head, like a cappuccino (spelling:?) The nose has vanilla then chocolate coming after. The taste is oak tannins  being a bit dominant, but then a creamy chocolate/coffee thing following. The palate is drying iniitially because of the oak and this dryness continues. Black with a small Brown head. Very rich aroma, cocoa, lots of toffee and chocolate. Rich sweet flavor, dusty cardboard, mild chili finish. Great beer

Bottle at BrewDog Edinburgh. Inky brown/black with a thick reddish brown head. Aroma of varnish, bourbon, smoke, hint of coffee. Taste is dry & slightly sour with plenty of woodsmoke flavours. Spicy chili finish. Interesting.

In bottle. Pours a lovely dark black colour with a thick brown head. Aroma is of bourbon barrels and tastes great, bourbon, malt and bitter chocolate flavours. Lovely oily mouthfeel with a lingering bitterness.

bottle thanks to bu11zeye.  poured black with a copper head.  aroma and flavor were chocolate, fudge, peppers, and something else unreadable in my notes.  body was a little thin for me.

(Bottle 7/4-2011) Its more balanced then the raw ranger, the bourbon mixes really nice with the chili and chocolate.
spicy chilli aroma,black, brown foam, light sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, long spicy finish.

Bottle. Huge tan head with good duration. Color is black. Aroma and taste are wood, coffee, chocolate, roast malt, licorice, caramel and hops.

Bottled, 020411.

text: Bottle, 375ml. Its black and looks unclear in the glass, a small tan head sits on top. Like the regular version, it has smoke, coffee and chocolate, as well as chili, hints of peanuts and sweetness, but its all a bit weaker. Theres also some alcohol and vanilla from the barrel, and a faint note of something reminiscent of cherry. The flavor has some vanilla and prunes, as well as smoke, coffee, chocolate, chili and sweetness. A touch of toluene too, but very faint. Warming and full-bodied. Chili warming that is, not alcohol warming. In the end the chili is more evident than in the regular version. A pleasant beer this one, but I prefer the regular edition. The barreling adds something to the beer, but it also smoothens out the other flavors and thats not what I want. 101015

Aroma has SOO much going on its nutts, peppers, chocolate, smoke, sweet honey, wet leather, earth. Medium bodied with light carbonation, heat upon finish that builds rather nicely. Big thanks to Jtclockwork for sharing this one. Pours out black with a one finger tan head. Aroma is chipotle, some light roast, earthy smoke, and light chocolate. Taste is very complex, lots going on. Chipotle, chocolate, bourbon, smoke, and some leathery earthy notes hanging in there also with an ever so slightly chili burn on the finish. This would be a great compliment to a mole. Awesome

Tasted at the big SeaBass has got to go tasting courtesy of hopscotch. Thanks Eric. Pours deep mahogany with mocha head. The aroma offers up black licorice covered chocolate balls and chocolate brownie as well as a mild level of sweet smelling bourbon. The taste has yummy toffee to dark chocolate notes to start and then running into some spicy black licorice followed by mild and sweet bourbon and wood. It leaves a nice fudge and black licorice sensation hanging around into the after taste.

Well after trying the regular version on tap at Cask in Pimlico, I had to get the BA version, I also have a 75cl of the normal version, which Im yet to try, so all my comparisons with this version are versus the keg regular. Pours out really oily, jet black and shiny, brilliant coloured head, deep mocha brown, thats the colour that all dark beer heads should be, proper job! Aroma is totally hedonistic. Supercharged rich chocolate truffles, dark choc, belgian choc, a whiff of tar, smoke, big mineral character, roasted coffee, roasted malts, thick vanilla and american oak, this is all held together by a nice amount of boozy Bourbon, but not at all over the top, finally you get a peppery hint of Chipotle Chilli, an aroma I have recently gotten to know very well and is now unmistakable.  Flavour is powerful but remains well balanced and nicely complex (what else would you expect?) Id say you get an initial burst of all the flavours at once, then they segment into mids and finish. The up front rush is all the aromas following on to the palate, with an added punch from the chili. As it breaks down the earthy, tar/smoky notes lead, then you get massive choco vanilla combo, with a real slick oily mouthfeel, then the pepper notes from the Chipotle start to fade in with Bourbon and dark chocolate, some more sweet toastiness from the oak, then back into more bitter choco, ash, mineral and finally the last burst from the chili to finish. Totally cracking stuff. My only complaint, is that I preferred the heat from the original, I feel here the aging has mellowed the chili heat, but on the plus side the oak has padded out (what was already a pretty dense body) even more and made it super drinkable. Top marks.

Thick black pour with a creamy brown head. Aroma of bourbon, vanilla, chili peppers, chocolate and espresso. Flavor is similar with bourbon, chocolate, roasty espresso and a bit of the peppers coming through.  Awesome.

Pours black with a brown head, Isobel (Lozs mum) said it tasted of stewed fags, whilst I cannot agree with that comment I did think that there was tobacco in there, along with some good bitter chocolate and a steady warmth. (375ml bottle, BB 15/06/13)  Pours a black body with a small brown head.  Aroma of roasted malt, chipotle, chocolate, smoke, and oak.  Flavor of roasted malt, chocolate, vanilla, caramel, some wood, and chipotle.  Excellent.

375ml silver wax dipped bottle, best by 06/15/2013.  Pours virtually pitch black, with the slightest possible glint of reddish-mahogany showing at the far outer edges in the presence of a strong backlight.  A small, foamy, medium-brown head pushes out to a solid, frothy ring with a wispy center film.  Small, rounded spots and short snakes of lacing mark the glass.  The nose is really quite nice.  Based in the obligatory dark chocolate malt, which comes across mainly fudgy and sweet, the barrel has imparted notes of fatty coconut, vanilla créme, and caramel kissed bourbon.  The oak influence seems to have covered up a bit of the smokiness from the chipotles, and while still present, the capsaicin spice has also been tamed, coming across more as a mild, fruity, fleshy pepper scent.  Smells quite delicious, actually.  The barrel has done the aroma well.  Flavors follow the same pattern, sweet dark chocolate showing most prominently, accompanied by caramel and mildly toasted, vanilla-kissed oak.  Coffee emerges as it warms, giving some roasty character.  Chipotles lend moderately spicy, peppery heat, but the star of the show is that creamy coconut, which again proves delicious.  Good stuff!  The palate is appropriately round and oily, very slick and viscous, with fine, active carbonation there to aerate it a bit.  Bittersweet chocolate concentrates on the slightly drying finish.  Very good brew overall.  The barrel marks a noted improvement over the base beer, without a doubt.
Black with a small tan head. Roast malt aroma with oak, licorice and caramel, and hint of bacon smoke and chili. Sweet licorice and ink roast malt flavour with notes of chili, oak and vanilla.

Thanks to bu11zeye for sharing this bottle. The original version was outstanding, I cant wait to try the barrel-aged version.

Medium to full mouthfeel and medium carbonation.
not the hotness and smokiness like the rogue chipotle ale, but what a special treat. Had this at the Borefts Beer Festival.

Can somebody PLEASE pass a law against the use of wax on bottles!!!

Taste: Surprisingly mellow; soft, smokey, slightly acidic finish, slightly bitter. Very accessible. Very powerfull flavours and yet not a very high abv - thats way cool, man. I push the overall to the top for that particular accomplishment.

Huge thanks to daknole! Bottle pours black with a dense beige head.  Aroma is bourbon, chocolate, oak, and chipotle.  Flavor shows the same with additional roast malt and vanilla.  Overall body is full, viscous and finishes dry with spicy bitter chocolate.

Bottle from Ølbutikken. Black with a light brown head. Coffee, intense vanilla and chocolate aroma. Good coffee bitterness, chcolate, delicious vanilla and hints of whisky, chili burns towards the finish. A special one.

Nice black pour with a fine light tannes head. Aroma has chili and smoke, soft bourbon notes, chocolate. Not much roast or coffee, but I really like the smell on this one. Taste has coffee, rather roasted,  dark caramel, the chili burns in the after taste. Velvety smooth carbonation. Really good!!

SO dark. Tar with a deep brown head.  Stinky cheesiness on the nose. Blue cheese and metallic confusion.  In the mouth it is sweet and light to begin with then it quickly tightens around the tongue and drops low into a smokey bourbon finish.  Vanilla is also detectable.
Black as night with a dark brown head.  Bourbon, coffee, chocolate, peppers in the aroma.  Flavor is sweet bourbon with a kick from the chocolates, peppers, roast.  Char.  YUM.

Bottled. Almost pitch black coloured. huge dense light brown head. aroma of coffee, chocolate, spice, grass, herbs, light caramel. Vanilla, sweetness, coffe, chocolate, vague smoke, herbs, wood, light alcohol and on it goes in the flavour. Medium to full bodied. Has a smoked, chocolaty and bitter touch in the end. Very vague chili bite notable. Me like.

Bottle at home. Pours an opaque black with a beige head. Smells of smoked malts and vanilla/wood. Sweet and dry with aromas of smoked malts, roasted malts, mild chilli and wood. Also some residual sugars (that works well with the chipottle) Full bodied. Soft carbonation. Long finish with aromas of sour coffee and toeasted malts.

Bottled. A black beer with a huge brown head. The aroma has notes of roasted malt, chocolate, lemony hops, wood, and vanilla. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of caramel, roasted malt, and chocolate as well as lighter notes of smoke, vanilla, and chili.

37.5 cL bottle, courtesy of Ungstrup. Pours dark brown to black with a chocolate brown head. Aroma is wooden, vanilla, vegetables and dark roasted malt. Dark wooden and smoked malt flavoured. Mild bite and vegetabel. Lingering sweet caramelish and light vanilla. Distinct chili bite.

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2012 Bottle 37,5 cl. Courtesy of Ungstrup. Pours a pitch black with a dark brown head. Sweet hard roast malt in the nose with a whiff of smoke. Solid body, a little low in carbonation, hard roast malts, some smokiness and a whiff of the chili that leaves a slight tickle on the tongue. The Bourbon barrel however is rather downplayed. Rather subdued bitterness. 250810

Bottle at ChrisO "Im Trying to see the Stool" pre GBBF2010 tasting. Lots of barrel age on the aroma.  Some goodish stout like falvour.  I dont like the barrel ageing.  Bit of chilli flavour on the end.  OK.

[BBD 10] Dark brown color with a small, light tan head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of roasted malts, some cocoa, light pepper, vanilla, and smoke.  Taste of roast, some vanilla, bakers chocolate, smoke, and a peppery finish.

Bottle 375ml. @ ChrisOs Pre-GBBF Shindig 2010.[ Raise The Roof Tasting ]. Clear dark brown - black color with a large, frothy to creamy, good lacing, fully lasting, light brown head. Aroma is heavy malty, roasted, burnt, chocolate, bourbon - wood - oak. Flavor is heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration, wood - oak, dry, chili - peppery finish. Body is medium to full, texture is oily - creamy, carbonation is soft, finish feel is light alcoholic - peppery - chili ! [20100731]

31st July 2010. ChrisOs Pre GBBF - Raise The Roof tasting. Opaque black beer. Thick light brown head. A little malt and peat on the nose. Softish palate. Chilli heat but nicely balanced with some vanilla oak and soft dark malt. Very drinkable.

Bottle @ Chrisos pre-GBBF Raise the Roof Tasting 10. Poured with a disappearing, light brown, encircling head and a black body with very dark brown edges. Quite oily on the glass too. Chocolate, liquorice, raisin & prune and virginia tobacco aromas. Lovely warmth, chocolate - both milk leading to dark - tobacco, oak, bourbon and a BBQ meaty, smokiness. Soft, thick and oily mouthfeel. Creamy and lingering on the tongue.

Black colour, small brown head. Aroma is ashy, quite liquoriceish, toffeeish and mildly chocolate, alcohol and some coffee as well. Flavour is quite much the same with a nice alcoholic wooden touch to it.

Black with a large dark beige head. Sweet aroma with burned malt, chili, dark chocolate, chili, espresso and mollasses. Flavour was dry and chili made it spicy. Packed with burned malt, dark chocolate, plenty of hops, bourbon and wood. Finished with a chili burn.

Bottle at home.
Pitch black coloured with a medium sized beige head.
Sweet and roasted aroma of dried fruits, bourbon, vanilla and chocolate.
Sweet and roasted flavour of dried fruits, bourbon, vanilla and chocolate with notes of alcohol and chili pepper.
Roasted and warming finish.

02-AUG-2010, bottle @Mikkeller.
I wanted to taste this side by side with the regular Texas Ranger, but that was sold out at the bar - no wonder:)
Fantastic appearance with high lasting dark brown head on a black body. Looks like a dessert.
Nose is warm and maybe a bit alcoholic. Roasted flavors and bourbon flows from the glass.
Taste is roasted as well with that fine bourbon addition - and then the chili kicks in. Maybe not as apparant as the regular? Anyway, I like that the chili is not in your face, but just something that adds to the complexity together with the bourbon barrel aging.
I do not really detect any hops. Has the barrels killed that or were they not there in the first place? Hard to believe with a Mikkeller brew.
So is this better than the regular? Maybe just slightly - but I would be happy with a couple of bottles of the regular in stead of one 37cl bottle barrel aged at the same prise.
Anyway very fine brew.

Bottle at Chris Os Raise the roof tasting. Black pour with a tan head. Dark chocolate, coconut, caramel and toffee aromas. Very nice nose. Chocolate, light spices, malts and smoky flavours. Nice, malty action. Good alcohol burn. Nice.
Bottle at chrisos pre-GBBF Raise the Roof Shindig 10. Black with a brown head. Tarry chocolate aroma. Sweet After Eights taste. Sharp bitter finish.
375 ml bottle. Black with big brown head. Flavour is roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, bourbon, wood and chipotle.
bottle at chris o pre GBBF ...eep black ... rich dry chocolate roast malt ... big toffee ... big roast ... little chilli ... little boubon ... nice

Bottle 37,5 cl. A pour as black as they gets with an impressive dark brown head that just stand massive with a fluffy foamy attitude. The nose is sweet malty with lots of roastyness and coffee notes. You sense the mild smokyness andsome smooth wooden flavours. The taste is awsome. Rarely you get a bourbon aged beer that are balanced. too often the bourbon cask turn the most lovely beers in to sweet vanilla bombs that are so sweet that you hardly can finish your glass. You can taste the smoke and the mild burn from the chipotle chillies wild the roasty the sweet and the bitter notes blends together in perfect balance. The oak and the smoke also seems to go hand in hand ver ver nice. The mouthfeel is rather thick and one should think that we were dealing with a beer with a mutch higher alcohol percentage. The finish is long and joyfull with a mild throatburn from the chillis. I think it is impressive that not the bourbon aging nor the chilliea are taking over the picture, but together adds to a very nice and unique beer. Lovely
Bottle at home - shared with Mette. Pitch black - brown head. Bourbon. Sweetness. Tartness. Nice smokey. Chilli bite. Coconut. Very smooth body. Barrel "sourness". High wooden. Lovely.

waxed bottle at mikkeller bar.
pitch dark, smooth light brown head. lacing. looks fantastic
aroma is roasted stuff, dark malts, licorice, wood, fantastic aroma
flavor is malty, roasted stuff,c hili, wood, toffee, brown sugar. the chili and stoutness makes this one pretty extreme, even for a mikkeller. tastes fantastic, the chili works fine in this one.
